restaurants.name: ROOH
restaurants.title: Modern Indian Gastronomy Expert
restaurants.address: 333 Brannan Street Suite #150, San Francisco, CA 94107
restaurants.excerpt: Modern Indian gastronomy with creative cocktails. Inventive, modern, and theatrical, Chef Ashish draws on city dining and festival street-food memories to create bold, playful courses that will delight you.

popup.chefBio:
Chef Ashish Tiwari leads the culinary vision at ROOH San Francisco, where he serves as Head Chef of one of the Bay Area's most celebrated modern Indian restaurants. With over a decade of experience across luxury hospitality brands in India, the Middle East, and the U.S., Chef Tiwari brings a refined global perspective to Indian cuisine. His culinary philosophy is rooted in authenticity, artistry, and evolution—making him a driving force behind ROOH's success and a standout figure in the modern Indian culinary movement

At ROOH, he is known for:
  • Innovative menu development that blends traditional Indian flavors with modern techniques and seasonal California produce
  • Kitchen leadership across a highperforming team, ensuring consistency, creativity, and excellence in execution
  • Elevating guest experience through visually stunning plating and bold, balanced flavor profiles
  • Operational oversight, contributing to ROOHs continued recognition in the Michelin Guide and its reputation as a destination for progressive Indian dining

menu.content:
Amuse Bouche

Enchilada Bites – Enchilada tart topped with desi guacamole and a trio of zesty sauces

Course One (Vegetarian)

Aloo Tikki Benedict – Spiced potato cakes topped with tempered vermicelli and Spinach & lime mousse

OR

Tofu Koliwada – Crispy Tofu with curry leaf-tomato pachdi, podi masala, and pickled chili

Course One (Non-Vegetarian)

Coastal Balchao – Fiery Goan-style prawns, Naan wafer

OR

Tandoori Korma Chops – lamb Chops glazed in korma Sauce, masala aloo, dosa crisp

Course Two (Vegetarian)

Quinoa & Spinach Kofta Curry – Soft koftas in a rich gravy, paired with paneer roulade

OR

Lentil Cake – Steamed lentil cakes, tangy yogurt sauce

Course Two (Non-Vegetarian)

Butter Chicken – char-grilled chicken, Classic creamy smoked tomato curry

OR

Rangoon Shrimp Curry – Butter-tossed shrimp, peanut butter salan, bonito flakes

Sides: Saffron rice, Rooh dal, and assorted Indian breads

Dessert

Kheer Cheesecake – A fusion of creamy cheesecake and traditional Indian rice pudding

holi.content:
Amuse-Bouche

Thandai Espuma with Saffron Caviar & Almond Crumble (D) – Aromatic thandai mousse topped with edible flowers and almond dust, a chilled start to the festival of colors

Appetizer (Choice of One)

Awadhi Mushroom Éclair (D)(G) – A delicate cardamom-scented choux shell filled with melt-in-the-mouth mushroom galouti, finished with dehydrated curry leaf dust

OR

Duck Galouti Éclair (D)(G) – A delicate cardamom-scented choux shell filled with melt-in-the-mouth duck galouti, finished with dehydrated curry leaf dust

Palate Cleanser

Guava Chili Sorbet with Kala Namak Air – A playful nod to Holi street flavors, guava, chili, and black salt balanced in a refreshing sorbet

Entrée (Choice of One)

Jackfruit & Morel Kofta with Kashmiri Chili Walnut Sauce (G)(N)(D) – Crisp kofta stuffed with morel chunks & dust, served over silky chili walnut emulsion and beetroot crisps

OR

Seabass Moilee with Gunpowder Crumb – Pan-seared seabass glazed in Alleppey moilee, finished with curry leaf oil and crisp gunpowder crumbs

Dessert

Bhang Panna Cotta with Betel Leaf Dust & Fennel Meringue – A subtle and sophisticated twist on traditional Holi flavors

D - Dairy | G - Gluten | N - Nuts

restaurants.name: Tiya
restaurants.title: Progressive Indian Cuisine Expert
restaurants.excerpt: Progressive Indian cuisine with bold coastal flavors. Coastal sensibility meets classic Indian spice. For this menu Chef Pujan revisits seaside family meals, reimagining those comforting flavors with a contemporary twist.

popup.chefBio: I was born and raised in Kolkata, in a humble farming family. My roots are deep in the soil - quite literally. As a child, I would often run errands for my mother, like picking fresh carrots or tomatoes straight from our farm. Those moments of connecting with the land gave me immense joy, but they also planted a deeper understanding in me-that harvesting a crop is not the end; it's just the beginning of a much larger vision. That vision shaped my path in life. I always loved cooking for family and friends during gatherings and special occasions. After completing my education in Kolkata, I set out on a new journey-to the Culinary Academy of India in Hyderabad, under the guidance of my mentor and brother, Chef Sujan. Stepping into that academy opened a whole new world for me. I learned not just how to cook, but how to create. I began to understand that a dish is more than just food-it's a reflection of who you are, a story you tell through flavors and techniques. After graduation, my journey took me across the world. I joined the Princess Cruise Line in the United States, boarding in Los Angeles.

restaurants.name: Bombay Brasserie
restaurants.title: Heritage North Indian Master
restaurants.excerpt: Elegant dining with heritage North Indian dishes. Deeply rooted in North Indian traditions, this menu celebrates rich, slow-cooked flavors.

popup.chefBio: Chef Thomas G. Palamootil brings over 25 years of distinguished culinary expertise, honed through his extensive career with the Taj Group of Hotels, one of the world's most iconic names in hospitality. A native of Kerala, India's renowned spice capital, Chef Thomas's earliest influences came from traditional home kitchens where spices, freshest catch, and seasonal ingredients shaped everyday cooking. Inspired by these roots, he pursued formal culinary education and began his professional journey with Taj Hotels in 2001. Over the years, Chef Thomas has held key culinary positions with Taj across Kochi, Chennai, Bangalore, and Mumbai working alongside some of India's most respected chefs while mastering a wide spectrum of regional cuisines. He has worked with some of the leading restaurants with Taj hotels and even being part of international delegations. A defining milestone in his career was his role in the launch of Bombay Brasserie at Taj Campton Place, San Francisco, where he successfully introduced authentic Indian.

restaurants.name: Amber India
restaurants.title: Contemporary Indian Specialist
restaurants.address: 25 Yerba Buena Ln, San Francisco, CA 94103
restaurants.excerpt: Contemporary Indian with a luxe twist on classics. Polished and refined, Amber's tasting brings forward heirloom recipes and celebratory dishes with luxury ingredients.

popup.chefBio: Hailing from Kolkata, India, Chef Shibiraj is currently heading the culinary team at Amber India SF. He honed his talent by working at top hotel chains in different parts of India. In his long career he has received numerous culinary awards. We are excited to see what new directions Amber India SF will go toward under his leadership.

restaurants.name: New Delhi Restaurant
restaurants.title: Legacy Institution Master
restaurants.excerpt: A legacy institution blending tradition and hospitality, Chef Ranjan offers a homage to recipes and ceremonial dishes, reinterpreted for a modern fine dining audience.

popup.chefBio:
In Calcutta, hometown of Chef Ranjan Dey, Holi is called Dol. This very special festival is celebrated with great fanfare in every household. Dol has several cultural nuances, making it different from how it is celebrated in other parts of India. A special dish served at Dol is sweetened lal doi, or Mishti Doi in Bengali.

Drawing on that rich heritage, Chef Ranjan crafted a special, never-before menu to bring you the joy of Holi, as he first knew it, now reimagined for San Francisco's tables.

This is the Calcutta that he has known and loved.

A joyful city of colorful streets, and layered flavors.

Today, he calls San Francisco his home, and New Delhi Restaurant is his life's work.

This 37-year old restaurant is set in a 110-year-old Beaux-Arts ballroom, evoking a Maharaja's banquet hall, and honored by the City and County of San Francisco as a rare Legacy Business.

Chef Ranjan has made it his mission to bridge cultures through the art of food.

Come dine here during Indian Restaurant Week, and if you happen to catch him on the floor, he has an anecdote to tell you.

Every plate carries his personal story.

holi.content:
A Bengali Springtime Multi-Course Feast

Welcome Drink

Doi with Mishti Jhol – Light sweet yogurt infused with cardamom

Shubho Aarombho (Starters)

Basanti Pulao Arancini – Crisp saffron-scented rice balls with a hint of cashew and raisin

Koraishutir Kochuri – Flaky stuffed breads with green peas and Bengali garam masala

Served with Tetul-Khejur Chaatni – Tamarind and date chutney with dry roasted spices

Mains

Basanti Pulao – Fragrant yellow rice with ghee, saffron, and nuts

Koshaa Mangsho – Slow-cooked goat curry with caramelized onions and garam masala

Chingri Malaikari – Prawns simmered in coconut milk with bay leaf and whole spices

Dhokar Dalna – Pan-fried lentil cakes in a tomato-ginger gravy

Begun Bhaja – Crisp fried eggplant, simple, nostalgic, essential

Mishti Mukh (Desserts)

Malpua with Rabri – Soft fritters soaked in syrup, served with warm sweetened condensed milk

After-Meal Ritual

Gondhoraj Lebu Chaa – Tea scented with fragrant Bengali lime, cleansing and uplifting

restaurants.name: Copra
restaurants.title: South Indian Coastal Expert
restaurants.excerpt: Regional South Indian fare with a modern coastal influences guide Copra's menu. Bright chutneys, coconut-rich textures, and the seaside spice combinations that mark festival feasts.

popup.chefBio: Chef Srijith Gopinathan is a celebrated figure in the culinary world, particularly noted for his innovative approach to Indian cuisine. He earned two Michelin stars during his tenure at Campton Place in San Francisco, where he served as executive chef for 15 years. Originally from Kerala, India, Chef Gopinathan Gopinathan brings a personal touch to his cooking, drawing on family recipes and childhood memories. His other ventures include co-owning Ettan in Palo Alto and Little Blue Door in Los Altos, showcasing his diverse experience in the food industry.
